Bug.WithStack:

i'm not offered to create bar as an abstact method don't think we should. have to try to keep the number of proposals small. to change a method to a abstract method is not hard: add the abstract modifier and use quick fix to remove the body *** Bug 37842 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 56310 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 108338 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** (In reply to comment #1) > don't think we should. have to try to keep the number of proposals small. > to change a method to a abstract method is not hard: add the abstract modifier > and use quick fix to remove the body

Bug.Summery: [WorkbenchParts] Restart with a clean state
Bug.WithStack:
When opening a (too) big source file into a specific editor (including a specific parsing), it can happen that a java.lang.OutOfMemoryError occurs, asking the user to exit the from the workbench.
Fine, but relaunching Eclipse causes an open action to be made again, fail again, and quit again,..., until the user removes the big file from the workspace...
It looks like an attempt to open a file (big, or wrong, or whatever) broke the whole workbench forever... Not sure whether this is a feature request or a bug. Definitely a bug.
Can you reproduce this in the latest 2.1.1 build?
I've reproduced this with the build M20030602-win32 and the N20030601-win32. Thanks in advance. Martin Can you provide us with a test case using the Eclipse SDK? That is, can you provide steps to reproduce this using the basic text editor, or the java editor? Mmm, I tried with the Java Editor or the default text editor, but no success. The original use case is decribed in the Bugzilla 37424, and describes the OutOfMemory exception occuring when parsing and opening a big C++ source file. That is why I believe that the easiest steps to reproduce this is to have the CDT installed, and open a big source file that I can provide. With the recent changes to error handling in the workbench, you will get an error part, and not be forced to shut down, assuming the file is read in createPartControl, not init. Stefan, can you confirm?
The error part is only created for recoverable exceptions, and wouldn't be created for OOMEs (it will also be created for init exceptions -- there is a PR open requesting this to change when init is called inside IWorkbenchPage#openEditor or showView, but this hasn't been fixed yet).
However, the workbench now only updates its active part after the new part is fully initialized -- so if an OOME occurs in the new part, it will still consider the old part active when the workbench reloads. This may be fixed, but it will be annoying to try to reproduce.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When opening a (too) big source file into a specific editor (including a specific parsing), it can happen that a java.lang.OutOfMemoryError occurs, asking the user to exit the from the workbench.

It looks like an attempt to open a file (big, or wrong, or whatever) broke the whole workbench forever... Not sure whether this is a feature request or a bug. Definitely a bug.
Can you reproduce this in the latest 2.1.1 build?
I've reproduced this with the build M20030602-win32 and the N20030601-win32. Thanks in advance. Martin Can you provide us with a test case using the Eclipse SDK? That is, can you provide steps to reproduce this using the basic text editor, or the java editor? Mmm, I tried with the Java Editor or the default text editor, but no success. The original use case is decribed in the Bugzilla 37424, and describes the OutOfMemory exception occuring when parsing and opening a big C++ source file. That is why I believe that the easiest steps to reproduce this is to have the CDT installed, and open a big source file that I can provide. With the recent changes to error handling in the workbench, you will get an error part, and not be forced to shut down, assuming the file is read in createPartControl, not init. Stefan, can you confirm?
The error part is only created for recoverable exceptions, and wouldn't be created for OOMEs (it will also be created for init exceptions -- there is a PR open requesting this to change when init is called inside IWorkbenchPage#openEditor or showView, but this hasn't been fixed yet).
However, the workbench now only updates its active part after the new part is fully initialized -- so if an OOME occurs in the new part, it will still consider the old part active when the workbench reloads. This may be fixed, but it will be annoying to try to reproduce.

Bug.Summery: [WinCE]Palette switching problem on SH4 WinCE (BBAWT)
Bug.WithStack:
I am attaching a testcase which illustrates some sort of palette switching problem in SWT running on an SH4 board with WinCE. The problem is that the colors pink and orange aren't initially visible; they paint as black instead. However, if you switch away from the test app and return, you then see the pink and orange blocks. Once painted correctly, as you switch away from the test app again, you can briefly see the colors revert to black again.
Note that this should be considered low priority until we hear from the customer that this is a significant issue for them. Created attachment 4994 java source code CC to investigate and advise. Will this be addressed in 3.1? Doesn't look like it. Chrix, did you make any progress on this? No. Note that it is not on a regular Pocket PC. Your bug has been moved to triage, visit http://www.eclipse.org/swt/triage.php for more info.

Bug.Summery: [CVS UI] Need better indication of an unsupported server version
Bug.WithStack:
When I try to checkout a module from our repository, it stops after checking out only a few files. I don't see any error message or warning. But when I use the command line version of cvs on our Solaris machines it checks out the complete module properly. Any way for me to debug this? Would it be helpful if I sent over sample copies of the files as they are stored in our repository? It is strange that this would fail since Eclipse does not do anything special when checking out modules. What checkout menu action did you choose (Checkout as Project, Checkout As or Checkout Module)? I could believe that there were problems using Checkout As Project. If this is what you tried, please try Checkout Module.
Also, what Eclipse build are you using? Hi Michael, I am using Eclipse 2.1 on Windows NT 4.0. A correction: I actually didn't check out a module, but a project. I right clicked the project and chose, "Checkout As..." then I selected "Java project". Our cvs repository is on Solaris 8 and I believe our cvs version that we're using is 1.10. This particular project contains java and c++ code and I don't know if there's any significance, but eclipse seems to stop checking code out from the directory in this project that contains the non-java code. (It checks out one directory before this that contains java code). Here is a listing of this directory with the native code:
total 325 -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 277 Nov 19 1999 Art.def -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 45257 Dec 7 1999 Art.odl -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 6132 Dec 1 1999 ArtClassFactory.cpp -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 620 Nov 19 1999 ArtClassFactory.h -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 159687 Aug 28 2000 ArtImpl.cpp -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 52373 Dec 7 1999 ArtImpl.h drwxrwxr-x 2 dickmda risk 512 May 28 20:35 CVS/ -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 10336 Nov 19 1999 DispatchImpl.cpp -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 3652 Dec 1 1999 DispatchImpl.h -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 14531 Dec 1 1999 DllServer.cpp -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 610 Nov 19 1999 DllServer.h -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 16603 Aug 28 2000 JavaVM.cpp -rw-rw-r-- 1 dickmda risk 2244 Dec 1 1999 JavaVM.h ~/FWR/ART/src/art/automation>
eclipse seems to stop after only checking out "Art.def" from this directory. Eclipse supports CVS 1.11.1p1 and beyond. Please upgrade your server version and reopen if the problem still occurs. Invalid due to unsupported server version. Thanks, we'll try that. Is there any way for eclipse to detect which version of cvs is being used and then show an error message if the version used is not recent enough? That would prevent this from being an issue for other people. Eclipse does detect the server version. However, it is a bit intrusive to throw up an error dialog and prevent operation so the message is written to the log. We upgraded to cvs 1.11.5 which does the trick. Thanks!
However, I think that a warning box should be displayed if someone is using a version that is too old as this will help people avoid having to waste time troubleshooting on their end. Maybe a one time warning box which is displayed the first time eclipse goes against a server version that is too old, but has a check box which the user can check so that this warning will not be displayed again next time eclipse communicates with that particular pserver.
To be honest this lack of eclipse working with our version of cvs was a huge reason why many people in my group at work didn't want to start using eclipse. Since no one knew what the issue was they interpreted this problem with cvs as a failure with eclipse instead of a failure with cvs since our command-line tools "just worked" but eclipse didn't.
Feel free to close again if you don't agree with my thinking. The Error log is more prominant in 3.0 so the unsupported warning is a bit more visible. fair enough. thanks.

Bug.Summery: PrecisionRectangle calculates width and height incorrectly
Bug.WithStack: The integral width and height of a PrecisionRectangle are being calculated incorrectly. The wrong way is to take the REAL width and cast it to an INT. The right way is to take the REAL *right edge*, subtract the integral X value, and then convert that to an INT. fixed
Bug.WithOutStack: The integral width and height of a PrecisionRectangle are being calculated incorrectly. The wrong way is to take the REAL width and cast it to an INT. The right way is to take the REAL *right edge*, subtract the integral X value, and then convert that to an INT. fixed

Bug.Summery: Hard to distinguish rows in Palette column layout
Bug.WithStack:
The alternating labels and icons run together in large drawers.
Two changes have been made. There is more vertical space between rows. There is less vertical space between 2 or more lines of text in a label. The font leading was removed from FlowUtilities. fixed
Bug.WithOutStack:
The alternating labels and icons run together in large drawers.
Two changes have been made. There is more vertical space between rows. There is less vertical space between 2 or more lines of text in a label. The font leading was removed from FlowUtilities. fixed

Bug.Summery: Move and Resize Handles off by one during Zoom
Bug.WithStack: Certain Zoom levels cause rounding errors in the placement of both the move handles and resize handles. The fix is to use a PrecisionRectangle. fixed
Bug.WithOutStack: Certain Zoom levels cause rounding errors in the placement of both the move handles and resize handles. The fix is to use a PrecisionRectangle. fixed

Bug.Summery: TooltipHelper does not size to preferred size
Bug.WithStack: TooltipHelper is measuring the tip's preferred size and using that, instead of the root figure, which adds a line border, therefore changing the overall preferredsize. This affects palette tooltips, which wrap their text when they shouldn't. Eric - the fix has been released, but try to investigate why this didn't affect Labels useds as tooltips. Looks fine to me.
Bug.WithOutStack: TooltipHelper is measuring the tip's preferred size and using that, instead of the root figure, which adds a line border, therefore changing the overall preferredsize. This affects palette tooltips, which wrap their text when they shouldn't. Eric - the fix has been released, but try to investigate why this didn't affect Labels useds as tooltips. Looks fine to me.

Bug.Summery: Package Browser not redrawing correctly
Bug.WithStack:
This appears to be an OS X platform specific problem. I have a package with a large number of classes in it (> 20). When I open this package in the package browser (flat setting). The package opens (the arrow turns down) But the window does not get redrawn showing the files inside of it. I have the package browser set in fast view mode and have to close the fast view and reopen it (I assume forcing a repaint) which then displays the files inside of it.
This behavior does not occur when a package has only a few files in it. I have not tested it to determine the break point.
I am running on a 12" PowerBook, 867 Mhz 640MB Ram with the VM's memory capped at 256. Transferring to SWT. SSQ to investigate and advise.
I believe this is a duplicate of Bug#36334. Are the items drawn, if you click in the area where the new items are supposed to be? This does appear to be the same issue. forcing a redraw or clicking at random shows that the tree is expanded just not drawn.

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] Provide a titled separator
Bug.WithStack:
A separator with title is often a good replacement for group boxes. It helps developers align grouped components, where the Group prevents many developers from aligning components inside the group with other elements outside the group.
You may consider providing an option for the title's position: left, middle, right, default.
This is related to rfe#38058: "overuse of group boxes". In Photon a Group box looks pretty much like a separator with title. I think JFace could provide this feature, not SWT. SN to advise. Platform UI is in charge of Eclipse branding issues. Please feel free to contribute a component for possible inclusion in jface There are currently no plans to work on this feature

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] DCR: Add a gradient separator
Bug.WithStack:
A gradient separator improves the design flexibility and helps designers organize elegant panels.
A gradient separator is a good alternative to groups, etched separators and white space. A thin gradient can separate two panel sections without drawing too much attention to the separator. It is good choice if plain white space may confuse the user.
You can find elegant horizontal and vertical examples of such a gradient separator in the Windows XP login screen. SN to advise. Interesting, I'm giving this to Platform UI because Eclipse branding issues are not SWT work items until approved by the UI designers. There doesn't seem to be a native gradient separator and gradients go in and out of fashion! We're talking to the graphic designers about improvements to L&F for R3.0. Kevin, could you give them this suggestion?
I think the Forms library provides some of what is requested here and the rest is somewhat out of date

Bug.Summery: [KeyBindings] KeySupport.java should support localized key sequences

Lines.Line: 3. Select any item in the Commands box
4. Press the pull down button next to the Key secuence field

Bug.WithStack:
Translator had a question about the need of certain strings to be externalized.
Key values are in English in the Keys Preferences page.
Steps to recreate: 1. Select Window -> Preferences 2. Select Workbench -> Keys 3. Select any item in the Commands box 4. Press the pull down button next to the Key secuence field
Question from translator: We observed that the keys are displayed in English, however there is a file named: eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.ui.workbench\workbench_jar\org\eclipse\ui\internal\c ommands\keysupport.properties that seems to contain the translation for the keys. Should these keys be translated or should they be displayed in English? Should consider for 2.1.1 fixed in 2.1.1. translator can now translate keysupport.properties. translator should make sure that no spaces are used in the translation as spaces are used to delimit keystrokes.
keeping problem open until i can migrate fix to 3.0
fixed in 3.0 The keysupport.properties has already been translated. Will this fix, make the translations viewable, or is retranslation needed?
Note the english file does have spaces in it. this fix will make the translations viewable.
the fix includes an updated properties file which does not have any keys or values containing whitespace. leading and trailing whitespace around keys and values is automatically stripped, so it is not the concern. rather the concern was around a few two word keystroke values such as 'Arrow Up' and 'Arrow Down', etc. these have been renamed 'Arrow_Up' and 'Arrow_Down' until such time as we have a proper widget to insert key strokes wihout requiring text typing. the spaces currently interfere with the text widgets parsing of multiple keystroke keysequences, where each keystroke is delimited by a space.

Bug.Summery: [Viewers] CheckboxTreeViewer.setChecked() takes a very long time.
Bug.WithStack:
Build: 2.1 GA. The checkbox tree in question is on the 'Plug-ins and Fragments tab of the the runtime workbench configuration. This tree can potentially contain > 1000 elements, but it's only two levels deep. If I call the method setChecked(Object, boolean) a thousand times in a row, the operation takes ~30 seconds. Calling setCheckedelements(Object[], boolean) yields the exact same result. I'm guessing this method in turn calls setChecked(Object, boolean).
Note that when I use a checkbox table viewer, as we do on the PDE > Target Platform page, calling CheckboxTableViewer.setChecked(Object, boolean) a thousand times takes ~ 1 second.
CheckboxTreeViewer.setChecked() is thus definitely using an inefficient lookup algorithm. Are you using setUseHashlookup(true) in both cases? It tried it both ways, it made no difference. Wassim, since you have a test case for this already set up, would you be able to step through it? I'm surprised by this, since findItem should find the corresponding TableTreeItem quickly due to the map lookup, and TableTreeItem.setChecked simply delegates to TableItem.setChecked, which should therefore have the same performance characteristics as as the CheckboxTableViewer scenario. Nick, note that the problem that I'm having is with the "CheckboxTreeViewer", not "TableTreeViewer". I just tested it this morning with 3.0M1 and with the setUseHashLookup(true) flag, and it worked like a charm. In the past when the setUseHashLookup(true) did not do make a difference, it could be that I inserted it at the wrong place (e.g. after the setInput(..) method was called). Thanks Nick. setUseHashlookup() has: Assert.isTrue(getInput() == null, "Can only enable the hash look up before input has been set");//$NON-NLS-1$
So I don't think that could have been the case. Is it possible it wasn't getting set at all before? It was there, but commented out. So I must have thought at some point that it was having no positive effect and there was no reason to keep it around.

Bug.Summery: Index out of bounds from Combo.select()
Bug.WithStack:
The Javadoc for the org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Combo.select() methods says that indecies that are out of range are ignored by on the Mac platform I get the following exception:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Index out of bounds at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2318) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2262) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.error(Widget.java:506) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Combo.select(Combo.java:1155)
I found the following line in the source code, which I assume is where the exception is being thrown:
if (0 > index || index >= count) error (SWT.ERROR_INVALID_RANGE);
This causes the Mac platform to behave differently then other platforms and from the way the document says it should work. fixed in HEAD > 20030529

Bug.Summery: Java attribute wizard does not allow legal nested folders
Bug.WithStack:
Build: I20030528
The Java attribute wizard erroneously treats all source folders with more than one segment in their path as illegal. The only thing that should be illegal is if a source folder is nested within another *source* folder. Adjusted such that Java Attributes Editor will disallow nested folders only within a source folder.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: I20030528
The Java attribute wizard erroneously treats all source folders with more than one segment in their path as illegal. The only thing that should be illegal is if a source folder is nested within another *source* folder. Adjusted such that Java Attributes Editor will disallow nested folders only within a source folder.

Bug.Summery: Tracker implementation on GTK incomplete
Bug.WithStack:
Tracker widget does not offer resize functionality on SWT/GTK.
SWT/Windows and SWT/Motif versions operate as expected - the resize code works (but buggy) as expected. Note that the test case from bug 36610 should be tried when this is implemented.
Released fix > 0529 that provides the RESIZE functionality on GTK. The only piece that's missing is the warping of the pointer, since Display.setCursorLocation() claims that this is not supported by GTK. Will revisit this issue to verify, so am keeping the report open for now.
Also added keyboard accessibility to GTK's Tracker. Still no pointer warping though.
Pointer warping is not currently available through gtk or gdk, and we can't assume that X is underlying, so XWarpPointer cannot be used. Marking report as FIXED since the gtk Tracker implementation has been completed to the extent that's possible. Will keep an eye open for the introduction of this facility in future gtk releases.

Tracker widget does not offer resize functionality on SWT/GTK.

Bug.Summery: No "package prefix" in runtime extensions in plugin.xml
Bug.WithStack:
While I haven't collected timing data, I think initial classloading would be faster if a package prefix was provided. With the core tools loaded, and the right options specified, I see a lot of "did not match org.eclipse.xsd' messages get dumped to console. I assume these are "false searches" which could be short circuited if there was some hint given by package prefix. David,
We'll make this change to all our plugins. It didn't measurably improve the performance of the tests I did, but maybe in an environment with hundreds of plugins, it would make a bigger difference. This is fixed for all the EMF and XSD plugins. Move to verified as per bug 206558. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: New quick fix that removes the assignment from a parameter that has been removed from signature [quick fix]
Bug.WithStack:
Before the refactoring you have
foo(int a) { this.fA = a; ... }
After refactoring "a" out of the signature you get
foo() { this.fA = a; ... }
Now I would like to have a quick fix that deletes the assignment to the field. The same could happen to the field, if it is not accessed any more in the class. What you want is a 'remove statement' quick fix whenever there is an unresolved element error in your statement (element could be variables, methods or types)
After considerations I think it's better to not offer that. First reason is that we have to be careful of not having too many quick fix suggestions per error. If the list gets too long your forced to read all suggestions and selection takes more time, making the feature less valuable (in my opinion). The list for unresolved element is already quite big: Create field, parameter, local var. Second reason is that removing references is a very hard problem: Most statements have possible side effects e.g. method calls and it's not possible to decide if they can be removed or have to be kept: user interaction is required.
setting to WONTFIX

Reverse typing on JSP page with taglib
Bug.WithStack:
On a jsp page, when import a new taglib and start to use it, Eclipse begin to type reversed. To stop this, is necessary to close the page and reopen Aldo,
Eclipse doesn't have build-in JSP support. Are you using a thrid party plug- in ? If so, please report the bug to there. Closing since Eclipse doesn't have JSP support. Suspect that this is cause by a third party plug-in.
Bug.WithOutStack:
On a jsp page, when import a new taglib and start to use it, Eclipse begin to type reversed. To stop this, is necessary to close the page and reopen Aldo,
Eclipse doesn't have build-in JSP support. Are you using a thrid party plug- in ? If so, please report the bug to there. Closing since Eclipse doesn't have JSP support. Suspect that this is cause by a third party plug-in.

Bug.Summery: Add RMIC support
Bug.WithStack:
Seems strange that RMIC is not supported - can this be added to 3.0? This isn't on the list for now. Usually JDKs provide such tools rather coupled with the runtime libraries.
May reconsider later. dup

Bug.WithStack:
An unexpected exception has been detected in native code outside the VM. Unexpected Signal : 11 occurred at PC=0x79E63F15 Function=(null)+0x79E63F15 I'm using RedHat 9 (XFree86 4.3 , gtk2-2.2.1-4 ). This problem has happened with JDK 1.3.1_02 and JDK 1.4.1_02. Two cases where this happens every time for me: 1) Go to Run... 2) New JUnit 3) Select 'All Tests in Projects, Source Folder..." radio button 4) Hit 'Apply' then run.
As soon as the progress bar gets to 100% the JVM crashes.
The same crash (same error in gtk_progress_bar) also happens when adding a new perforce server to the p4eclipse plugin ( 0.61 )

Bug.Summery: Image encoders should support various depths

Lines.Line: 24-bit-direct, since Image.init() blits the 4-bit indexed data into
*** Bug 168071 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
I see the same behavior as comment #5 on MacOS X

Bug.WithStack:
Image encoders (note: encoders, not decoders) are only currently guaranteeing to work with an ImageData as provided by the matching decoder. This is not very useful since to really manipulate the ImageData a user often needs to create an Image and then gets a different ImageData back.
Image encoders should check the ImageData passed in and use the internal ImageData.bitblit call to convert it to a supported format (depth/scanlinepad/palette features). If a user needs more elaborate control over the details of image encoding (level of compression etc.), a third party library dedicated to handling image formats will have to be used. The proposed change will only serve the basic needs. Do I understand correctly that this bug was split off from Bug 38186, and that voting for this bug will allow people to save images as GIF files? Saving an ImageData as a GIF is expected to work if your image data is of bit depth 1, 4 or 8. If you wish to be able to save into GIF an image with a different bit depth, yes you can vote for this PR. ICO probably needs to handle more depths also. Here's the current depths handled: boolean isValidIcon(ImageData i) { if (!((i.depth == 1) || (i.depth == 4) || (i.depth == 8))) return false; int size = i.palette.colors.length; return ((size == 2) || (size == 16) || (size == 32) || (size == 256)); }
*** Bug 120722 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Also, from the newsgroup: [Eclipse 3.2M3, gtk]
Snippet194 (write an animated gif) throws with message "Unsupported color depth" under linux.
This is because the return value from Image.getImageData() is always 24-bit-direct, since Image.init() blits the 4-bit indexed data into 24-bit direct data. *** Bug 168071 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I see the same behavior as comment #5 on MacOS X
Even though I'm creating an Image using Indexed (isDirect == false) ImageData with a depth of 4 (or 8), the image created always has a depth of 32 and is direct, due to the Image.init() blit call, resulting in "unsupported color depth" errors when using ImageLoader.save
Can you verify whether or not this will be addressed as part of the Linux-GTK duplicate bug so.... is there a solution for this problem? i'm trying to create some ImageData instances and put them into an array for the imageLoader instance, and it still gives me the depth error. i do not want that the ImageData instances will be restricted to a very few number of colors... please help.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Image encoders (note: encoders, not decoders) are only currently guaranteeing to work with an ImageData as provided by the matching decoder. This is not very useful since to really manipulate the ImageData a user often needs to create an Image and then gets a different ImageData back.
Image encoders should check the ImageData passed in and use the internal ImageData.bitblit call to convert it to a supported format (depth/scanlinepad/palette features). If a user needs more elaborate control over the details of image encoding (level of compression etc.), a third party library dedicated to handling image formats will have to be used. The proposed change will only serve the basic needs. Do I understand correctly that this bug was split off from Bug 38186, and that voting for this bug will allow people to save images as GIF files? Saving an ImageData as a GIF is expected to work if your image data is of bit depth 1, 4 or 8. If you wish to be able to save into GIF an image with a different bit depth, yes you can vote for this PR. ICO probably needs to handle more depths also. Here's the current depths handled: boolean isValidIcon(ImageData i) { if (!((i.depth == 1) || (i.depth == 4) || (i.depth == 8))) return false; int size = i.palette.colors.length; return ((size == 2) || (size == 16) || (size == 32) || (size == 256)); }

Even though I'm creating an Image using Indexed (isDirect == false) ImageData with a depth of 4 (or 8), the image created always has a depth of 32 and is direct, due to the Image.init() blit call, resulting in "unsupported color depth" errors when using ImageLoader.save
Can you verify whether or not this will be addressed as part of the Linux-GTK duplicate bug so.... is there a solution for this problem? i'm trying to create some ImageData instances and put them into an array for the imageLoader instance, and it still gives me the depth error. i do not want that the ImageData instances will be restricted to a very few number of colors... please help.

Bug.Summery: [content assist] Dynamic Code Assist to support
Bug.WithStack:
The current CodeAssist framework is somewhat static in nature:
Editors register IContentAssistProcessor/s, and when the action is executed, these processors submit an array of ICompletionProposal/s.
CodeAssist will bring up a small shell window/s to list the proposal, and execute the given operation that is selected. This works well if the only thing that is relevant is the current cursor position as it is related to logical structure of the text.
It will be a great advantage to add *current text cursor* position (in addition to the current mouse cursor position) to contribute to a dynamic content stimulation.
Example use case scenario: The Visual Editor for Java (currently ships with the WebSphere Studio products) provides a split pane view of text and GEF representation of the text. It is very likely that when the user is in the source pane (see attached figure) the content of code assist should also reflect the current mouse position.
In the attached figure, the user wanted to add code that takes the information from the JTextField, and add it to the JList when the JButton is pressed.
The user selects on the JButton (on the GEF canvas), use the context menu to add an actionPerformed event skeleton. The cursor is then positioned on the body of the event callback The user now wants to create the code to add the text field info to the JList. At this point a getJList() or (the instance variable name) jList proposal would have been quite helpful. This proposal would be changed as the mouse is moved around to other components.
Currently there is no support to change the proposals list, as the cursor moves around the GEF canvas; nor is there support to open the code assist shell around where the mouse cursor is (outside the text editor). Created attachment 5002 Use case example

Bug.Summery: Variables should be allowed to contain other variables/lists
Bug.WithStack:
It would be great if a variable could be defined that could represent a variable or a list of variables. For example, I have JBoss installed and several other libraries that are used by JBoss and my applications.
I'd like to be able to define JBoss=/usr/local/jboss JBoss_J2EE=${JBoss}/lib/j2ee.jar JBoss_JMX=${JBoss}/lib/jmx.jar
and also JBoss_ALL=${JBoss}/lib:${JBoss_J2EE}:${JBoss_JMX}
and then use JBoss_ALL in my projects.
I know that I can define the three variables seperately, but I use a lot of projects where I'm using JBoss along with various other standard groupings of Jar files. Ideally, I'd prefer not to have to set up each variable for each project that I use, but instead set up a pseudo-variable that I use for each project type (JBoss or J2ME) which then defines a related set of project libraries.
Although bug 36960 describes the idea of a project template (which in itself it would be very handy) it wouldn't capture any changes that were made to the template to existing projects that had already been instantiated using the project template.
Perhaps this could be considered for the 3.0 release along with the fix for bug 36960 Are you talking about classpath variables ? The syntax you picked doesn't seem to refer to these. Oops. Yes, you are right -- I was referring to classpath variables. PS Was using syntax from a Bash-like shell to explain how I'd like to use them, rather than necessarily that being the syntax they are used in Eclipse, because of course at the moment variables cannot refer to other variables ... Variable entries can only denote one item. Classpath containers are rather to be used to abstract sets of libraries. However, there is no UI at the moment to handcraft your owns. Yes, I know -- that's why I raised this bug :-)
However, allowing variables to refer to other variables would be a very neat solution to this problem. You then already have the ability to represent these nesting issues; in any case, the capability to 'extend' a variable is already in the platform. All I'm suggesting is that a variable may be defined by extending another variable, as opposed to a single classpath entry to be an extended variable. That, in conjunction with defining a variable as a 'group' of jars would solve this problem.
Note that there are several situations where this would be useful; J2EE with Struts; MIDP 2.0 and Nokia extensions; J2EE with JSTL etc. Then you could define a project to use a 'standard' set-up of the MIDP2_NOKIA rather than having to remember to include each variable individually. And what about abstracting all these inside a project which exports its libraries ? Then you could construct all combinations you want. I'm not sure what you are referring to when you say 'these' -- can you rephrase what you said? Thanks. You could abstract your set of libraries through a Java project which you can then require on other project's classpath. This library project simply needs to include these JARs on its build path and tag them as exported (to dependents).
You can define multiple of these library projects, and have them export each other if you need to achieve some nesting.
Also projects can be shared across source control...
So taking your example, I could imagine defining a Java project named "JBoss", and have it denote all the JARs you would refer through the variable JBoss_ALL. It would export these libraries.
Then some project would simply prereq the JBoss project and that would be it.
One more advantage for this solution is that if at a later stage you want to have sources for JBoss or change its layout, then you would simply need to reorganize the JBoss project accordingly. Clients could be left unchanged, since they don't known about its internals.
You could also separate JBoss project into several smaller projects (JBoss_J2EE, JBoss_JMX) so as to achieve finer granularity of reuse. Also, using projects, you can better browse code into the proper context (JBoss implementation isn't mixed inside client code) and when defining working sets to scope search, projects are quite handy. For all these reasons, we went for a simple variable story, relying on the fact there was much more powerful ways to achieve more complex stories. I understand what you mean now :-) Yes, using a project as a placeholder certainly does allow you to build the projects up in terms of a standard set of libraries.
I also like the fact that this configuration is then stored in source control as well.
If you mark this bug as 'invalid' then I'll verify it. Sounds good to me. Closing then.

Bug.Summery: [api] Code Assist images
Bug.WithStack:
Code Assist proposals are reflected as an Image and Text. The images that are used in the JDT proposals are generated by org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.text.java.ResultCollector. Though it makes use of the JavaElementImageProvider.getFieldImageDescriptor() to get the proper image for a particular IJavaElement, it does perform additional consideration for elements like static, deprecated, Local variable etc.
We are interested to contribute to code assist by way of reusing the images (and semantics) that are in use by the (internal) ResultCollector. Do you expect that the collector gets public API or flags/API to get the images for the content assist? We are generating/reuse codeAssist proposals, and would like to provide the same semantics as does the ResultCollector when it comes to assigning images to proposals elements (see attached image). The JavaElementImageProvider gives us image mapping for regular IJavaElement kind of things, but it lacks the additional semantics the ResultCollector provides for locals, deprecation etc.
We ask for a complete public support in JavaElementImageProvider.
Created attachment 6719 Screen Scrape Martin, you are the master of JavaPluginImages and also wrote most of that ResultCollector.
I agree that it makes sense to offer clients a way to get the same images for content assist proposals as we have. I see two choices: either we add yet another flag or we provide a new class for accessing the content assist proposal images.
Feel free to move back after commenting if you think this is now in Jdt Text area. ResultCollector is not likely to become public API. It is just too closely connected to the Java editor. The idea is to offer all images in 'ISharedImages' and let you (other plugins) write something like the JavaElementImageProvider yourself for your kind of elements. This gives you the most flexibility and us less API to maintain.
I see that we are not providing the field and local variable images and also missing most of the inner type images. I will add that to ISharedImages.
I'll have a look if it would be good to have methods like 'getMethodImageDescriptor(boolean isInInterface, int flags)' in 'ISharedImages' as well.
In fact we could rewrite JavaElementImageProvider to use the constants in 'ISharedImages' to see if we're offering enough in the API.
Let me know if that makes sense to you.
Yes. It makes a lot of sense. ISharedImages updated to caint the full set of images for Java elements > 20040418 > 20040418

Bug.Summery: JETEmitter throws ResourceException if .JETEmitters directory exists

Lines.Line: 1. In Eclipse Package Explorer, right-click .JETEmitters project and select
2. In Confirm Project Delete dialog, select Do not delete contents and click

Bug.WithStack:
Steps to reproduce: 1. In Eclipse Package Explorer, right-click .JETEmitters project and select delete. 2. In Confirm Project Delete dialog, select Do not delete contents and click Yes. 3. Invoke JETEmitter on a template
Problem: org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.JETException[0]: org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Resource /.JETEmitters/src already exists. at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkDoesNotExist (Resource.java:291) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.checkDoesNotExist (Resource.java:265) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.assertCreateRequirements (Folder.java:23) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:84) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Folder.create(Folder.java:114) at org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.JETEmitter.initialize (JETEmitter.java:272) at main.MyJETEmitter.initialize(MyJETEmitter.java:231) at org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.JETEmitter.generate(JETEmitter.java:421) at main.Main.generate(Main.java:169) at main.Main.run(Main.java:112) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.PluginAction.runWithEvent (PluginAction.java:251) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetSelection (ActionContributionItem.java:456) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:403) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.access$0 (ActionContributionItem.java:397) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem$ActionListener.handleEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:72) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:81) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.sendEvent(Widget.java:840) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:1838) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1545) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:1402) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:1385) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run (InternalBootLoader.java:845) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:461) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke (DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:291) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:747) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:583)
When JETEmitter creates the .JETEmitters project, the "src" and "runtime" folders are created without checking if they exist:
(line 272-273)
project.getFolder(new Path("src")).create(false, true, new SubProgressMonitor (progressMonitor, 1)); project.getFolder(new Path("runtime")).create(false, true, new SubProgressMonitor(progressMonitor, 1));
Suggested fix: Check if each folder exists before creating them.
IFolder src = project.getFolder(new Path("src")); if (!src.exists()) { src.create(false, true, new SubProgressMonitor(progressMonitor, 1)); } IFolder runtime = project.getFolder(new Path("runtime")); if (!runtime.exists()) { runtime.create(false, true, new SubProgressMonitor(progressMonitor, 1)); } Remko,
We've made the suggested change. Thanks! Fixed in build 20030616_1530VL. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: Deleting a Drawer in the PaletteCustomizer doesn't update selection
Bug.WithStack:
Use the customizer to create a new palette drawer. Use UP/Down keys to place that drawer between the two existing Logic drawers.
Now delete the drawer. The Name Text control still displays "New Drawer". During handleDelete(), I set the TreeViewer's selection to be the previous sibling to the item being deleted. If the item being deleted is at the top of its siblings, the next sibling (which will be the first sibling after the delete) will be selected. When this new item is selected, the name Text control updates accordingly.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Use the customizer to create a new palette drawer. Use UP/Down keys to place that drawer between the two existing Logic drawers.
Now delete the drawer. The Name Text control still displays "New Drawer". During handleDelete(), I set the TreeViewer's selection to be the previous sibling to the item being deleted. If the item being deleted is at the top of its siblings, the next sibling (which will be the first sibling after the delete) will be selected. When this new item is selected, the name Text control updates accordingly.

Bug.Summery: Surfacing new buid properties in a global preference page
Bug.WithStack:
As the build now provides more flexibility through a few new properties, I think it could worth trying to surface those in a global preference page so that the user does not have to set it for every build.xml it writes
Here are the properties. javacFailOnError javacDebugInfo javacVerbose javacSource javacTarget Pascal, do you have setters on your generators that I could set these values, as entered by the user? There are no setters for those values. We do not want the values for those variables to be hardcoded in the script.
The idea I had in mind when I open this bug, was to automatically set the values in the properties of the launch for the build.xml. Pascal, it would be great if you could provide a short description for each property, as I'm not sure what some of them do. I'll use the descriptions in the preference page that I will create for these settings. Thanks. javacFailOnError : Indicates whether the build will continue even if there are compilation errors; defaults to true. javacDebugInfo : Indicates whether source should be compiled with debug information. javacVerbose : Asks the compiler for verbose output. javacSource : Determines the source code format. Legal values are 1.3 and 1.4. javacTarget : Generate class files for specific VM version. Note that the default value depends on the JVM that is running Ant. Thanks Pascal. One more thing though. You mention that javacFailOnError defaults to true; however, in the generated scripts that I'm looking at, the value is "false" by default. Which should the correct default value be? You are right, it is false. I copied the Ant doc a bit too fast :-) Remove the last part of the comment. Done. Will be in tomorrow's I-build.

Bug.Summery: Border width on Table incorrect - creates unwanted scrollbars
Editing an external tool builder modifies the .project file
Bug.WithStack:
When simply editing an external tool builder, we should not need to make any changes to the .project file. It was whitespace in the launch configuration handle (an arg of the command) that was causing the problem).
Fixed in BuilderPropertyPage. Changed name of WorkingSetComparator to IgnoreWhiteSpaceComparator. Please verify Jared. Verified code.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When simply editing an external tool builder, we should not need to make any changes to the .project file. It was whitespace in the launch configuration handle (an arg of the command) that was causing the problem).
Fixed in BuilderPropertyPage. Changed name of WorkingSetComparator to IgnoreWhiteSpaceComparator. Please verify Jared. Verified code.

Bug.Summery: .project file contains contains a project specific path
Bug.WithStack:
From bug 37943: "Checkout project as", which we MUST be able to use, allows you to checekout the a CVS project to any location/folder you choose. We have a build.xml in the root of the project folder tree. So we must be able to reference the build.xml relative to where the project is placed, not the workspace.
The .project file contains contains a project specific path to the .externalToolsBuilder folder. This path should be project relative. Making sure I understand the issue here...
Reading this comment in the context of Bug 37943, it sounds like the request is to expand the ${project_loc} variable inside the context of an external tool builder to mean the project enclosing the builder.
This seems like a separate issue from the way we store the handle to the launch in the .project file, right? I think they are separate issues.
Re-reading this, since external tool builders are project specific I don't see how having a project specific path can be harmful here? But at the same time I don't see any reason that the path for the external tool builder launch file can't be project relative. The .project's path to the .externalToolsBuidler folder must be specified relative to $project_loc. Otherwise, "Checkout Project As" will be trying to use the externalToolBuilder folder from eclipse/workspace/<default CVS module name> instead of from eclipse/workspace/$project_loc We store the memento that we get from the launch configuration. Then there may be bugs here in the debug framework. We need to do some testing with the workflow that P Duffy is using. If you checkout the org.eclipse.ant.core project as "Ant Core" (or some other name) and go to the External Tool Builders for the project, it displays "Invalid External Tool Builder".
This should be an issue for anyone who called ILaunchConfiguration#getMemento() on a config stored in a project. For our purposes, at least, we know that external tool builders are always stored inside the .externalToolBuilders folder. So we should be able to manipulate the memento to store a project-relative path and then rebuild the correct memento when we want to get the config.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 37944 ***

Bug.Summery: Support WAS as well as Tomcat for online help system
Bug.WithStack:
The eclipse help system running on iSeries needs to support WAS as well as Tomcat. The memory footprint for running both application servers is too great on the iSeries platform. It is not clear to me what your requirement is. What is your usage scenario that you are trying to solve with specific installation/configuration?
Eclipse supports both (and more servers). It runs embedded an embedded Tomcat, but you can contribute a another plugin providing Appserver functionality and it will be used _instead_. See org.eclipse.help.appserver.server extension point. Eclipse being open source, cannot provide WAS specific implementation of a plugin.
Tomcat in Eclipse can be replaced by another server implementation, so essentially this bug has been fixed long, ago.
There is no response whether this bug concerns totally different problem, but there exists a plan item bug 37714, that I think this bug is a duplicate of. The bug 37714 goes beyond enabling Tomcat to be replaced with another server, and the bug has iSeries point of view presented. I will mark this as a duplicate then. Please continue the discussions in the plan item bug to identify the issues and possible solution regarding WAS and Tomcat.

Bug.Summery: [Viewers] [Javadoc] Incomplete javadoc for DialogCellEditor

source_code.code:
/** * Opens a dialog box under the given parent control and returns the * dialog's value when it closes, or null if the dialog * was cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog. *

* This framework method must be implemented by concrete subclasses. * It is called when the user has pressed the button and the dialog * box must pop up. *

* * @param cellEditorWindow the parent control cell editor's window * so that a subclass can adjust the dialog box accordingly * @return the selected value, or null if the dialog was * cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog */

Bug.WithStack:
The javadoc for #openDialogBox() does not say how to indicate that the dialog box was canceled. The de-facto behaviour is that if null is returned, it is considered as "cancel". I assume you mean the method declaration in class DialogCellEditor? yes Clarified the spec for openDialog as follows: /** * Opens a dialog box under the given parent control and returns the * dialog's value when it closes, or null if the dialog * was cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog. *

* This framework method must be implemented by concrete subclasses. * It is called when the user has pressed the button and the dialog * box must pop up. *

* * @param cellEditorWindow the parent control cell editor's window * so that a subclass can adjust the dialog box accordingly * @return the selected value, or null if the dialog was * cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog */ I'm viewing this as a spec clarification, not a breaking API change, since callers would have already had to handle null.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The javadoc for #openDialogBox() does not say how to indicate that the dialog box was canceled. The de-facto behaviour is that if null is returned, it is considered as "cancel". I assume you mean the method declaration in class DialogCellEditor? yes Clarified the spec for openDialog as follows: /** * Opens a dialog box under the given parent control and returns the * dialog's value when it closes, or null if the dialog * was cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog. *

* This framework method must be implemented by concrete subclasses. * It is called when the user has pressed the button and the dialog * box must pop up. *

* * @param cellEditorWindow the parent control cell editor's window * so that a subclass can adjust the dialog box accordingly * @return the selected value, or null if the dialog was * cancelled or no selection was made in the dialog */ I'm viewing this as a spec clarification, not a breaking API change, since callers would have already had to handle null.

Bug.Summery: TVT21: Strings not externalized

Lines.Line: 2. Expand Workbench, click in Linked Resources
4. In New Variable panel, click on "Folder" button
5. The panel with problem is displayed.

Bug.WithStack:
Build Driver: 20030528 Reporter: Ricardo Mandl
Test case: 02.37700
Description: The panel "Select Folder" that is displayed when we click on "Folder" button is partially in English. Several fields, words are in English, like: "Folders","Selection" and "Cancel" button.
See attached images as example.
Steps to recreate: 1. Windows -> Preferences 2. Expand Workbench, click in Linked Resources 3. Click on New... button 4. In New Variable panel, click on "Folder" button 5. The panel with problem is displayed.
Comments:
This happens for all OS. Attached is a windows and SuSE screen shot. Created attachment 5007 Windows clip with untranslated strings Created attachment 5008 SuSe clip Should consider for 2.1.1 The window that is being talked about is the SWT DirectoryDialog. Reassigning the report to SWT for comment and copying VI. The DirectoryDialog is a native dialog. In order to see the text in the correct language, you must make sure your locale is correctly configured. SWT does not provide the strings displayed on these buttons and there is therefore nothing to NLS on our part.
*** Bug 38269 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Lynne, it looks like you have looked into this. Am assigning it back to you as you have more context than I do.
Can this be closed? If not then it needs to be resolved for 2.1.1. Closing. As indicated in comment #5, the locale has to be installed correctly. If the locale is installed correctly, but the strings are still not showing up correctly, this is a platform problem and any solution will have to be provided by SWT, not Platform UI. Should add the following to the readme for 2.1.1 and 3.0. Pending confirmation from Cam as to whether this is also still a problem on Windows.
Missing translations for certain dialogs under GTK You may find the translations of some dialogs such as File selection, Folder selection, New Folder, Delete, rename , etc... partially translated when running the NLS versions of eclipse or Websphere Studio Workbench on GTK 2.0.6 or GTK 2.2. These screen selections are coming from GTK, not eclipse or the workbench. For further information, please refer to this web site: http://developer.gnome.org/projects/gtp/. Gnome Bug 114658 was crested to report this problem.
Reopening because the PR is not invalid... ... it's a problem with the OS. Added this to 2.1.1 release notes:
Missing translations for certain OS dialogs (Linux GTK only)
OS dialogs for selecting files or folders are only partially translated on GTK 2.0.6 or GTK 2.2. These dialogs and the untranslated messages come from GTK, not from Eclipse. This is a known bug in GTK. (bug 38248)
I am unclear as to why a bug report was filed against Gnome.
I have logged into RedHat 9.0 Gnome with simplified chinese and the FileDialog is correct - all strings provided by the OS are translated. If the locale is correctly set, GTK+ does the right thing. We are using RedHat 8.0 with GTK 2.2., not RedHat 9.0. Please contact Tod Creasey for more information. This is the level of GTK that we use for all our DBCS testing and TVT.

Bug.Summery: NPE trying to create project builder
Bug.WithStack:
When you try to create an external tool project builder, an NPE occurs. The problem appears to be that while creating the contents of the refresh tab, we end up trying to validate the launch config. But this happens before the contents have been fully created, so we get an NPE when we try to access the working set component.
I don't know what's recently changed to cause this.
Here's the stack trace: Thread [main] (Suspended (breakpoint at line 233 in ExternalToolsBuilderTab)) ExternalToolsBuilderTab.isValid(ILaunchConfiguration) line: 233 ExternalToolsBuilderTab.canSave() line: 251 LaunchConfigurationTabGroupViewer.canSave() line: 846 LaunchConfigurationPropertiesDialog.updateButtons() line: 227 ExternalToolsRefreshTab(AbstractLaunchConfigurationTab).updateLaunchConfigurationDialog() line: 87 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.updateValidState() line: 225 ResourceComponent.validate() line: 205 ResourceComponent.updateResourceListEnablement() line: 159 ResourceComponent.createContents(Composite, String, IVariableComponentContainer) line: 64 LaunchConfigurationVariableForm.createVariableComponents() line: 169 LaunchConfigurationVariableForm.createContents(Composite, IVariableComponentContainer) line: 99 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.createScopeComponent(Composite) line: 113 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.createControl(Composite) line: 61 LaunchConfigurationTabGroupViewer.showTabsFor(ILaunchConfigurationTabGroup) line: 647 Occurs only on the latest code not in the build. The ResourceComponent was doing an unnecessarily early update of the resource list.
Please verify. There's also a problem with the launch dialog framework. The dialog and the tab viewer keep track of an "initializing tabs" state. However, this should only be maintained/checked in the tab viewer. Fixed. Moved "initializing tabs" state to tab viewer, and only check the state from the tab viewer. Please verify, Jared. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you try to create an external tool project builder, an NPE occurs. The problem appears to be that while creating the contents of the refresh tab, we end up trying to validate the launch config. But this happens before the contents have been fully created, so we get an NPE when we try to access the working set component.
I don't know what's recently changed to cause this.
Here's the stack trace: Thread [main] (Suspended (breakpoint at line 233 in ExternalToolsBuilderTab)) ExternalToolsBuilderTab.isValid(ILaunchConfiguration) line: 233 ExternalToolsBuilderTab.canSave() line: 251 LaunchConfigurationTabGroupViewer.canSave() line: 846 LaunchConfigurationPropertiesDialog.updateButtons() line: 227 ExternalToolsRefreshTab(AbstractLaunchConfigurationTab).updateLaunchConfigurationDialog() line: 87 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.updateValidState() line: 225 ResourceComponent.validate() line: 205 ResourceComponent.updateResourceListEnablement() line: 159 ResourceComponent.createContents(Composite, String, IVariableComponentContainer) line: 64 LaunchConfigurationVariableForm.createVariableComponents() line: 169 LaunchConfigurationVariableForm.createContents(Composite, IVariableComponentContainer) line: 99 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.createScopeComponent(Composite) line: 113 ExternalToolsRefreshTab.createControl(Composite) line: 61 LaunchConfigurationTabGroupViewer.showTabsFor(ILaunchConfigurationTabGroup) line: 647 Occurs only on the latest code not in the build. The ResourceComponent was doing an unnecessarily early update of the resource list.
Please verify. There's also a problem with the launch dialog framework. The dialog and the tab viewer keep track of an "initializing tabs" state. However, this should only be maintained/checked in the tab viewer. Fixed. Moved "initializing tabs" state to tab viewer, and only check the state from the tab viewer. Please verify, Jared. Verified.

and pick Refactor > Rename from the context menu

Observe: The name of the method in the Package Explorer

E.g., "getOriginalPosition" in private int getOriginalPosition(ASTNode node, List zelements); and pick Refactor > Rename from the context menu 2. Enter a new name for the method; e.g., "findOriginalPosition" 3. Tell the refactoring to proceed.

Bug.Summery: selecting method in Package Explorer does not scroll open Java editor

Lines.Line: 1) using the the single click mode

Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 2.1.1 build M20030528
Selecting a method in the Java Package Explorer does not scroll the open Java editor to show that method. It did in 2.1, so this is something that changed between 2.1 and this 2.1.1 build. The current behavior is not an improvement, since it now requires a double click on the method to scroll the editor. Further info: I was running with the Workbench > Open mode: Double click (the default). When I temporarily switched to Workbench > Open mode: Single click, selections in the Package Explorer now scroll the open editor (and open a new editor if necessary). When I then switched back to Workbench > Open mode: Double click, selections in the Package Explorer still scroll the open editor (but no longer open new editors). The bug has gone. If I shutdown eclipse and restart, everything is working fine when I restart.
I noticed this problem today when I upgraded from Eclipse 2.1 to this 2.1.1 build and kept the same workspace. This makes me suspect that the upgraded workspace was in a weird state. I switched back and forth between 2.1.1 and 2.1 a couple of times, and the bug looked reproducable. It wasn't until I started with Workbench > Open mode that the problem went away. I suspect the default setting are the problem. I tried hitting Restore Defaults, but the problem still hasn't come back.
This was changed to address https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=37567.
You can have single click behaviour by either: 1) using the the single click mode 2) by enabling the link mode.
closing - given the conclusion in bug# 37463.
opened a separate bug to apply the same fix as in bug# 22274 in the package explorer.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Eclipse 2.1.1 build M20030528
Selecting a method in the Java Package Explorer does not scroll the open Java editor to show that method. It did in 2.1, so this is something that changed between 2.1 and this 2.1.1 build. The current behavior is not an improvement, since it now requires a double click on the method to scroll the editor. Further info: I was running with the Workbench > Open mode: Double click (the default). When I temporarily switched to Workbench > Open mode: Single click, selections in the Package Explorer now scroll the open editor (and open a new editor if necessary). When I then switched back to Workbench > Open mode: Double click, selections in the Package Explorer still scroll the open editor (but no longer open new editors). The bug has gone. If I shutdown eclipse and restart, everything is working fine when I restart.
I noticed this problem today when I upgraded from Eclipse 2.1 to this 2.1.1 build and kept the same workspace. This makes me suspect that the upgraded workspace was in a weird state. I switched back and forth between 2.1.1 and 2.1 a couple of times, and the bug looked reproducable. It wasn't until I started with Workbench > Open mode that the problem went away. I suspect the default setting are the problem. I tried hitting Restore Defaults, but the problem still hasn't come back.
This was changed to address https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=37567.
You can have single click behaviour by either: 1) using the the single click mode 2) by enabling the link mode.
closing - given the conclusion in bug# 37463.
opened a separate bug to apply the same fix as in bug# 22274 in the package explorer.

Bug.Summery: How to deploy SWT/JFACE apps?

Lines.Line: 1) How do I build a swt/jface lib (what to include).
2) Why isnt jface packaged separatedly like stw?
3) How to deploy to non-programmers. I cant ask end
users to start my java app with various parameters
descriping where they installed the libs. I know that
webstart has some sort of mechanism for identifying
*.dlls and *.so files and knows where to put them. But
1) do you realy need to build swt lib (the native C code) ? why you don't
2) SWT is not responsible for JFace, JFace is develop by the UI Team. I can't
give a answer for this question.
3) This is an open problem, the swt libs are not part of java, therefore the
libs need to be copy to the appropriate place. What you can do is to provide a
script to launch your application, or maybe an executable like eclipse itself
does. You can see the source code of eclipse launcher, check out the module
platform-launcher from the eclipse CVS repository.

Bug.WithStack:
It should be easier deploying swt/jface based apps. I cant find any docs descriping how to deploy such apps. I need to know:
1) How do I build a swt/jface lib (what to include). 2) Why isnt jface packaged separatedly like stw? 3) How to deploy to non-programmers. I cant ask end users to start my java app with various parameters descriping where they installed the libs. I know that webstart has some sort of mechanism for identifying *.dlls and *.so files and knows where to put them. But what about regular non-webstart apps?
I am a complete eclipse newbie and while i have spent a lot of time looking for these answers, i havent found anything and it has turned out to be a major block. Other potential swt/jface programmers must be facing the same problems as me. Check the SWT page, the FAQ section. http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/dev.html
You can also find help in the newsgroup, check: http://www.eclipse.org/newsgroups/index.html
1) do you realy need to build swt lib (the native C code) ? why you don't download the binary instead. 2) SWT is not responsible for JFace, JFace is develop by the UI Team. I can't give a answer for this question. 3) This is an open problem, the swt libs are not part of java, therefore the libs need to be copy to the appropriate place. What you can do is to provide a script to launch your application, or maybe an executable like eclipse itself does. You can see the source code of eclipse launcher, check out the module platform-launcher from the eclipse CVS repository.

Bug.Summery: [feature] enhancents on task view

Lines.Line: - Export task list in formatted text, xml or others.
- Save task in CVS repository (dup of bug 26809)

Bug.WithStack:
It should be fine to add some features to the Tasks View: - Save task in CVS repository - Export task list in formatted text, xml or others. - Assign an owner to tasks - Save task in CVS repository (dup of bug 26809)
You can save tasks in the repository by using the java task tags. Look under Preferences > Java > Task Tags. For example, you create a comment like //TODO and it will show this in the tasks view.
- Export task list in formatted text, xml or others (see bug 21407).
This is also supported. If you select tasks in the task view, you can copy & paste into another application such as MS Word. You can also use drag and drop to export tasks into a text-based report in Word or WordPad.
- Assign an owner to tasks
There is currenlty no notion of users in Eclipse, so this would require a great deal of extra infrastructure
Bug.WithOutStack:
It should be fine to add some features to the Tasks View: - Save task in CVS repository - Export task list in formatted text, xml or others. - Assign an owner to tasks - Save task in CVS repository (dup of bug 26809)

This is also supported. If you select tasks in the task view, you can copy & paste into another application such as MS Word. You can also use drag and drop to export tasks into a text-based report in Word or WordPad.

Bug.Summery: File > New > build.xml
Bug.WithStack:
There should be a menu entry to create a basic build.xml that will compile the current project (taking into account current project properties such as build path etc).
The template it uses to generate the file should be customisable.
Possibly there should be several "basic" build.xml menu entries (covering different types of projects, such as webapps, ejbs etc).

Bug.Summery: Allow separate VM to be controlled at global level for Ant builds

Lines.Line: (1) Use default VM (which is controlled by global pref - may be same VM, may be

Bug.WithStack:
Create a global Ant preference to allow the setting of the default VM for Ant builds.
The global setting can be overridden by the per configuration setting We need to work with Java debug to come up with a better story for reuse of the JavaJRETab. The JavaJRETab has its own set of problems (needs to be more like the InstalledJRE preferencepage).
In Ant land we need to determine the definition of default: The VM set to build the project? The global VM set by the user? In the same VM as Eclipse? *** Bug 39249 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Pushing back to M3 I'm wondering if we need an more support that is currently available in 3.0M2. Currently you can "run in the same VM", or choose a specific (alternate, seperate) VM. The default behavior is to run in the same VM.
Will it be "too complex" to have the following options: (1) Use default VM (which is controlled by global pref - may be same VM, may be alternate) (2) Use alternamte VM (choose from drop-down)
The current implementation provides all the function. The only drawback is that is is inefficient (in user configuration/number of clicks), if you always want to use a certain (seperate) VM. Also inefficient if you want to change how all your 'default' scripts run - i.e. set them all to use the default VM, and then change the VM via a global preference.
Comments? (I'm not sure we know what the common use case is) I have heard from users that they want to easily be able to specify that all Ant builds occur in a specific separate VM. I am hesitant to redefine what "default VM" means in Ant land. I think of the default VM as the same VM as Eclipse. Did not make it for M3 *** Bug 46743 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** From M5 on Ant builds will by default occur in a separate VM (see bug 45899). As such I am lowering the priority on this one and moving to M6 for further consideration. Since we are focusing on bug fixes for M6 I am moving this to M7 Nothing more planned for 3.0 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Create a global Ant preference to allow the setting of the default VM for Ant builds.
The global setting can be overridden by the per configuration setting We need to work with Java debug to come up with a better story for reuse of the JavaJRETab. The JavaJRETab has its own set of problems (needs to be more like the InstalledJRE preferencepage).
In Ant land we need to determine the definition of default: The VM set to build the project? The global VM set by the user? In the same VM as Eclipse? *** Bug 39249 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Pushing back to M3 I'm wondering if we need an more support that is currently available in 3.0M2. Currently you can "run in the same VM", or choose a specific (alternate, seperate) VM. The default behavior is to run in the same VM.
Will it be "too complex" to have the following options: (1) Use default VM (which is controlled by global pref - may be same VM, may be alternate) (2) Use alternamte VM (choose from drop-down)
The current implementation provides all the function. The only drawback is that is is inefficient (in user configuration/number of clicks), if you always want to use a certain (seperate) VM. Also inefficient if you want to change how all your 'default' scripts run - i.e. set them all to use the default VM, and then change the VM via a global preference.
Comments? (I'm not sure we know what the common use case is) I have heard from users that they want to easily be able to specify that all Ant builds occur in a specific separate VM. I am hesitant to redefine what "default VM" means in Ant land. I think of the default VM as the same VM as Eclipse. Did not make it for M3 *** Bug 46743 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** From M5 on Ant builds will by default occur in a separate VM (see bug 45899). As such I am lowering the priority on this one and moving to M6 for further consideration. Since we are focusing on bug fixes for M6 I am moving this to M7 Nothing more planned for 3.0 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Subclassing the ZoomComboContributionItem
Bug.WithStack:
Subclassing the ZoomComboContributionItem
The comment for the fill method suggests that we override createControl to subclass. However, the combo control is private instead of protected, and toolItem, which may be used by a createControl that we subclass is private instead of protected.
refresh() doesn't have a modifier so it can be subclassed only from that package. Making combo, toolItem, and refresh() protected would be helpful, as well as possibly the handleWidget methods. What are you trying to do? Combo cannot be made available because we may be forced to use a CCombo in the future, due to how crappy Motif's Combo is. Hi, Randy. I was trying to add descriptive text items to the zoom combo such as zoom in and zoom out. AFAIK, This can be done entirely in the ZoomManager implementation. The ZoomCombo... only uses getZoomAsText, getZoomLevelsAsText, and setZoomAsText.
So, if your manager returns a string called "Zoom In", then choosing that will result in manager.setZoomAsText("Zoom In"). Don't forget that the strings will be translated.
I don't think putting "zoom in" and "zoom out" on the combo makes sense. They are Actions, not a choice. So, choosing the "zoom in" choice does not result in a consistent zoom setting, but a different one each time.
Visio and Word don't have such actions on their zoom combos. They do have "fit to page" and other choices, which could be done same way. These types of choices do give the same results each time (assuming the window isn't resized). I agree with you completely that the additional zoom in and zoom out can be implemented in ZoomManager. However, making getZoomLevelsAsText return those additional strings is strange, as you point out that these are actions. This is why I subclassed ZoomComboContributionItem.
How about at least making toolItem protected? FIT_PAGE, and other textual actions were added in 2.1.2 without any change needed.

Bug.Summery: Sync/Outgoing structure compare-ffile displayed as outgoing with no diffs displayed.
Bug.WithStack: I have seen files displayed in the synchronize/outgoing structure compare which do not display any diffs in the tesxt compare. This is quite common and can happen if the local file has been modified since it has been checked out but the contents match that of the server. To reset the timestamp of the file you can either perform a Team>Update or a Team>Commit
Bug.WithOutStack: I have seen files displayed in the synchronize/outgoing structure compare which do not display any diffs in the tesxt compare. This is quite common and can happen if the local file has been modified since it has been checked out but the contents match that of the server. To reset the timestamp of the file you can either perform a Team>Update or a Team>Commit

Bug.Summery: tools.jar needs to be updated when setting to run in a separate VM
Bug.WithStack:
The tools.jar entry on the Ant runtime classpath is not updated when the user specifies to run in a separate VM. We should add the Xerces JARs as well. Moving to M3 See bug 38815 as well.
The JRE tab for Ant now has an Update button. This updates the classpath based on the JRE that the user has selected. Please verify DarinW. To me, it's confusing to know when to use the "Update" button.
(1) When I select an alternate JRE, and the classpath tab says "use default", and I press the update button what happens? (does the "use default" get de- selected, and tools.jar get added?)
Perhaps we need a better classpath page... the meaning of "use default" might depend on what JRE is selected? (I need to understand this better). Question 1) the answer is yes. When you go back to the classpath page , use global will no longer be selected, and the correct tools.jar will be added to the classpath which is now launch configuration specific. Did not work when using an alternate JDK. I specified jdk1.4.1 which contains a tools.jar, and pressed Update - nothing happened. (Need to re-think this classpath stuff). In fact, I don't think we should need an "update" button (the classpath should auto-update if it's set to be "default"). If it's not default, then it's up to the user to change it.
I want to look into using a regular java classpath tab for this feature, with a "classpath provider". The Ant classpath does not have the same notion of default classpath. The launch config makes use of the global classpath (which the user can happily change) or overrides and provides its own.
The whole reason I attempted this is that the user has no idea what to update..thus the dozens of posts on the news group that Ant does not work because tools.jar is missing.
Looks like I just made things more complicated :-( Moving to M4 Initial re-work released. Created a new AntClasspathTab2 that uses the same classpath infrastructure as the JavaClasspathTab. The classpath is saved using the Java Application configuration format (memento of runtime classpath entries). The default classpath is computed by the AntClasspathProvider. "Container" entries now exist for ANT_HOME and "Additional Tasks & Support". The contents of these containers is computed dynamically at launch time. "Tools.jar" is a child of the addition support entry, and is computed to match the JRE being used.
TODO: * Remove unused code * Mark targets tab dirty when required (wasn't sure when to do this) For the configs it works for (including new ones), it looks great.
There must be some issues with moving older configs forward? I am getting a lot of my configurations showing a Classpath that only has a User Entries entry. Under that entry, there is a Project folder and under that is another Project folder? This all claims to be the default classpath.
As well the Ant runtime preference page will need to be reworked to be consistent (or is that in a separate bug?)
Other thoughts: do we really need the top level User Entries? * Config Migration: doesn't work. The classpath format has changed (could enter a bug to provide migration - i.e. if old attributes are present, reset the classpath) * Reworking the pref page: should be a new bug (feature) * Top level "User Entries": if we want to remove it, we can't re-use the java classpath model, but likely do-able. I added configuration migration to be more friendly. A config is migrated the first time it is opened in the tab or launched. I maintain the ANT_HOME setting, but ignore any other "custom classpath" settings (you get the specified ANT_HOME, and a default classpath). Fixed. I've entered bugs to cover migration issues and pref page issue (bug 53686 and bug 53688). I suggest to leave "User Classes" as the root node in the tab unless we get complaints - it maximizes our re-use. Please verify (I removed the old AntClasspathTab, and renamed the new AntClasspathTab2 to "AntClasspathTab"). When I change the designated JRE, the tools.jar entry is not updated. and it is not resolved correctly at runtime. Hmmm. Works for me. My test case: Create a brand new Ant launch configuration Set the buildfile Go to the JRE tab Set to a 1.3.1 VM Go to the classpath tab Still shows the 1.4.2 tools.jar in the Additional Tasks & Support Still works for me :-) ??? Is all the code released :-) The tools.jar was not updated if there was no global tools.jar. Fixed in ContributedClasspathEntriesEntry. Please verify DarinW. Verified.
